<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls (size_t size,
                                                        const void *buffer,
                                                        MHD_ContentReaderFreeCallback
                                                        crfc,
                                                        void *crfc_cls)
{
  struct MHD_Response *r;

  if ((NULL == buffer) && (size > 0))
    return NULL;
#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T >= SIZEOF_UINT64_T
  if (MHD_SIZE_UNKNOWN == size)
    return NULL;
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T >= SIZEOF_UINT64_T */
  r = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_Response));
  if (NULL == r)
    return NULL;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  if (! MHD_mutex_init_ (&r->mutex))
  {
    free (r);
    return NULL;
  }
#endif
  r->fd = -1;
  r->reference_count = 1;
  r->total_size = size;
  r->data = buffer;
  r->data_size = size;
  r->crfc = crfc;
  r->crc_cls = crfc_cls;
  return r;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:

                                                        crfc,

explanation: This function itself does not call any <string.h> functions, so the only places relevant to Rule 21.17 are where an external buffer pointer and its size are accepted, validated, and stored for later use. The listed fragments cover: the function parameters (buffer and size), the runtime checks that try to guard invalid combinations (NULL buffer with non‑zero size, the MHD_SIZE_UNKNOWN sentinel), and the assignments that record the pointer and size (and the free callback/closure which affect ownership and lifetime). Other code fragments in this function (memory allocation of the response object, mutex initialization, setting fd/reference_count, the free on allocation failure, and the final return) do not perform any string.h operations nor modify the buffer/size relationship used by potential string functions, so they are not relevant to Rule 21.17 and do not need investigation for out‑of‑bounds string accesses in this context.
